fields.body: Every month, we challenge all Repower@Home members to take one simple step to improve their energy use. This month, we're highlight the most effective tool you already own for reducing your heating and cooling bill: your thermostat. Everyone who programs their thermostat between now and February 28th will receive double the points for the action. Your thermostat may seem lowly, but it has the potential to make a huge difference. The secret: you have to use it. Around 70% of American households have thermostats,ENERGY STAR, Summary of Research Findings From the Programmable Thermostat Market but many of us are missing out on savings by not setting our thermostats correctly.Ibid. Saving money and energy with your thermostat is easy. Before you go to sleep or leave the house for the day, set back your thermostat. If you turn your thermostat from 72° to 62° during the winter, you could save 10% on your heating bill.U.S. Department of Energy, Energy Savers, Thermostats and Control Systems In the summer, raise your thermostat to 82°. It just takes a few moments every day, and you’ll quickly see real results. Programmable thermostats make saving energy automatic by raising or lowering your thermostat during certain times. There are many different models available, including ones that allow you to program different temperature settings for each day of the week. Your local home improvement store will likely offer a wide range of models. New models are also easier to set than some older versions. You can get started saving energy right away. Once programmed, you’ll never have to remember to set your thermostat again. You have everything to gain by programming your thermostat this month. Try it out, and let us know how it worked for you.

fields.body: At Repower@Home house parties, people often ask whether energy efficiency can really have an impact on climate change. Environmentally friendly actions like recycling or choosing reusable bags are definitely more visible changes than, say, insulating your attic. But while less obvious, steps that reduce your energy use at home are some of the most important things you can personally do to combat climate change. Direct energy use by American households accounts for around 38% of U.S. CO2 emissions.Dietz, Thomas et al., “Household actions can provide a behavioral wedge to rapidly reduce U.S. carbon emissions.” PNAS. 106.44 (2009) That means the emissions from American households are larger than the entire emissions of any other country except China. Ibid. Save money, Save the world The good news is that our homes represent an enormous opportunity to significantly reduce global greenhouse gas emissions. Homeowners across the country have already realized these savings. The average household that had a retrofit in Maryland, for example, reduced their energy use by more than 20%. Maryland Energy Administration, Maryland Home Performance with ENERGY STARE Even smaller steps, like reducing your hot water use and upgrading your lighting, start to add up to big rewards. Best of all, you can personally have an impact on climate change while saving money. Not only is investing in building efficiency the most cost-effective way to combat climate change, it’s actually an overall cost savings.McKinsey & Company, Unlocking Energy Efficiency in the US Economy Investing in energy efficiency is like paying yourself to do the right thing. Online and at our house parties, people across the country are getting geared up to make a big impact on energy waste and greenhouse gases. Together, we can make a real difference.

fields.body: The typical home consumed $2,200 in energy bills in 2009.ENERGY STAR, Where Does My Money Go? However, some tasks needed considerably more energy than others. Identifying the biggest energy users in your home will help you make targeted improvements and get the best return on your investment. Average Home Energy Bill By Task In the chart, you can see that heating and cooling is by far the biggest energy user in most homes. It’s responsible for almost half of your energy bill, costing the average home around $1,000 a year to run. Small, inexpensive improvements – like installing new air sealing – can add up to huge rewards. Hot water is another, surprising energy-guzzler. Just heating your hot water uses more energy than running your refrigerator, microwave, and other appliances. By becoming more mindful of your hot water use while showering or washing clothes, you can eliminate waste and higher bills.

fields.body:
Repower@Home is a fresh approach to saving energy. American homes consume almost a quarter of all the energy used in the United States. Unfortunately, much of this energy is needlessly wasted by outdated systems and habits. Repower@Home’s goal is to give you the power to reclaim that wasted energy and realize benefits like:
  • Lower monthly bills
  • A home that’s more valuable, more comfortable, and healthier
  • A cleaner environment
Tools for success Repower@Home will help you build a high performing, energy efficient home. Our online tools will give you personalized recommendations, connect you with local resources, help you track your progress, and allow you to share your achievements with friends and neighbors. Step by step, block by block, Repower@Home is giving people across the country the tools to restore, revitalize, and repower their homes. Where do we go from here? Repower@Home is a work in progress. As we grow, we’re excited to hear your feedback and suggestions for future content. As you click through the site, let us know how we’re doing by using the “Feedback” link up top. You’re going to be noticing a lot of new features in the upcoming weeks, so make sure to sign up for our email list to stay updated.
